The Battle of Ican (), occurred on 16 December 1864 near  as a part of the Russian conquest of Central Asia. In the battle, a Kokand army under the command of Alimqul was defeated by a cossack detachment.
Background
Colonel
After taking Shymkent, the Kokand khan Alimqul tried to return to the city secretly, but the Russians noticed small groups of the Kokand vanguard and sent a hundred cossacks under the command of  without knowing about real size of the Kokand army.
Battle
]]
As a result, the Kokand army surrounded the cossacks. At this time, a detachment of 150 people and 20 guns try breaking through to , but they received an order to retreat due to the large enemy army. The Cossacks shot back at the Kokand forces for two days, surrounded by the bodies of dead comrades and horses, and finally Alimqul sent them a letter:
}} Gunfire was heard in response. Serov understood that time was not on his side and he decided to break out of the encirclement. He gathered the remaining Cossacks and, shouting "hurrah" in the form of a Infantry square, attacked the enemies surrounding him and broke through their formation. The Cossacks retreated for several more miles, until finally a new expedition saved the detachment and took them to Shymkent on carts.
Aftermath
Participants of the Ican battle 20 years later The battle ended with the retreat of Alimqul. Russian detachment losing 2 officers, 5 constables, 87 cossacks, 4 artillerymen, 2 paramedics, and 2 Kazakh escorts.
